channel.title: Trekhleb.dev RSS Feed

item.title: Micrograd TS
item.description: A TypeScript version of karpathy/micrograd. A tiny scalar-valued autograd engine and a neural net on top of it.
item.content:encoded: A TypeScript version of karpathy/micrograd. A tiny scalar-valued autograd engine and a neural net on top of it.

item.title: Observations
item.description: My subjective observations, assumptions, questions, and interpretations about the world around us. Ultimate origin, science, Creator, theories, axioms, consciousness, universe, God's sensor, good vs evil, etc. Don't take it seriously.
item.content:encoded: My subjective observations, assumptions, questions, and interpretations about the world around us. Ultimate origin, science, Creator, theories, axioms, consciousness, universe, God's sensor, good vs evil, etc. Don't take it seriously.

item.title: Binary representation of the floating-point numbers
item.description: Anti-intuitive but yet interactive example of how the floating-point numbers like -27.156 are stored in binary format in a computer's memory
item.content:encoded: Anti-intuitive but yet interactive example of how the floating-point numbers like -27.156 are stored in binary format in a computer's memory

item.title: Content-aware image resizing in JavaScript
item.description: JavaScript implementation of so-called Seam Carving algorithm for the content-aware image resizing and objects removal. Dynamic programming approach is applied to optimize the resizing time.
item.content:encoded: JavaScript implementation of so-called Seam Carving algorithm for the content-aware image resizing and objects removal. Dynamic programming approach is applied to optimize the resizing time.

item.title: Making the Printed Links Clickable Using TensorFlow 2 Object Detection API
item.description: In this article we will start solving the issue of making the printed links (i.e. in a book or in a magazine) clickable via your smartphone camera
item.content:encoded: In this article we will start solving the issue of making the printed links (i.e. in a book or in a magazine) clickable via your smartphone camera

item.title: Generating cooking recipes using TensorFlow and LSTM Recurrent Neural Network: A step-by-step guide
item.description: I've trained a character-level LSTM RNN on ~100k recipes dataset using TensorFlow, and it suggested me to cook Cream Soda with Onions, Puff Pastry Strawberry Soup, Zucchini flavor Tea and Salmon Mousse of Beef and Stilton Salad with Jalapenos
item.content:encoded: I've trained a character-level LSTM RNN on ~100k recipes dataset using TensorFlow, and it suggested me to cook Cream Soda with Onions, Puff Pastry Strawberry Soup, Zucchini flavor Tea and Salmon Mousse of Beef and Stilton Salad with Jalapenos

item.title: NanoNeuron - 7 simple JS functions that explain how machines learn
item.description: The NanoNeuron.js code example contains 7 simple JavaScript functions (which touches on model prediction, cost calculation, forward/backwards propagation, and training) that will give you a feeling of how machines can actually learn. No 3rd-party libraries, no external data-sets or dependencies, only pure and simple JavaScript functions.
item.content:encoded: The NanoNeuron.js code example contains 7 simple JavaScript functions (which touches on model prediction, cost calculation, forward/backwards propagation, and training) that will give you a feeling of how machines can actually learn. No 3rd-party libraries, no external data-sets or dependencies, only pure and simple JavaScript functions.

item.title: Permutations/Combinations Algorithms Cheat Sheets

item.title: Dynamic Programming vs Divide-and-Conquer
item.description: In this article I’m trying to explain the difference/similarities between dynamic programing and divide and conquer approaches based on two examples - binary search and minimum edit distance (Levenshtein distance)
item.content:encoded: In this article I’m trying to explain the difference/similarities between dynamic programing and divide and conquer approaches based on two examples - binary search and minimum edit distance (Levenshtein distance)

item.title: Dangerous step from Agile to frAgile (fixed-requirements-Agile) software development
item.description: The dangerous step is — to FIX price, deadlines and vague scope for long-term project and at the same time try to be AGILE in development process.
